derivation.yuyuan_name: late Middle English: past participle of obsolete devoid 'cast out', from Old French devoidier

entry.def: If you say that someone or something is devoid of a quality or thing, you are emphasizing that they have none of it.

example.ex: I have never looked on a face that was so devoid of feeling...
example.tran: 我从来没有见过一张如此面无表情的脸。

example.ex: The skies are virtually devoid of birdlife.
example.tran: 天空中几乎没有任何鸟的踪迹。

auth_sentence.content: It turns out to be almost devoid of meaning.
auth_sentence.res_content: It turns out to be almost devoid of meaning.
auth_sentence.res_content_con: It turns out to be almost devoid of meaning.

auth_sentence.content: Sunderland were gritty and well-organised but devoid of inspiration.
auth_sentence.res_content: Sunderland were gritty and well-organised but devoid of inspiration.
auth_sentence.res_content_con: Sunderland were gritty and well-organised but devoid of inspiration.

auth_sentence.content: But, the White Beach is not devoid of appeal.
auth_sentence.res_content: But, the White Beach is not devoid of appeal.
auth_sentence.res_content_con: But, the White Beach is not devoid of appeal.

stems_affixes.word_buile: void空→adj.空虚的;没有的;无效的
un不+avoid[v.防止,避免;逃避,避开]+able能……的→adj.不可避免的
avoid[v.防止,避免;逃避,避开]+ance表名词→n.避免

sentences.en: This house is totally devoid of furniture.
sentences.cn: 这所房子里一件家具都没有。
